citation.article-title: Biochemical characterization of Serratia liquefaciens sensu stricto, Serratia proteamaculans and Serratia grimesii sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Serratia proteamaculans quinovora subsp. nov.

Serratia proteamaculans quinovora (quinovora is composed from the chemical name quinate (from Spanish quina, quinine; from Quechua kina, bark) and the Latin verb voro, to devour; hence, the Modern Latin feminine adjective quinovora, quinate-devouring)
In addition to the use of quinate as sole source of carbon and energy, S. proteamaculans subsp. quinovora can easily be identified by its failure to attack salicin and esculin in two days.
With API 2OE strips, this subspecies does not produce acid from amygdalin.

This proposal for a new subspecies within S. proteamaculans designates de facto the type strain of S. proteamaculans (ATCC 19323) as type strain of S. proteamaculans subsp. proteamaculans. Serratia protearnaculans subsp. quinovora has been isolated from plants, wild rodents, insects, and water, but not yet from human clinical specimens.
